Dear Ms. Lessnau:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation. • Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will
be completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved. •
The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4112 Staff qualifications
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
Description following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Unidentified staff are "mean" and mistreat Youth X.
Investigation I attempted to reach Complainant/Hospital Social Worker 1 via
phone and left a message with her dayshift counterpart conveying
that I was assigned to investigate the allegation.
I notified Youth X’s Foster Care Worker that I was the assigned
DCWL investigator. She indicated Youth X was in the emergency
room at Children’s Hospital and she had no concerns regarding
Christ Child House.
I spoke with Chief Administrator (CA) on 4/12/23. She was
already aware of the allegation. CA said Christ Child House
submitted a 30-day request to DHHS to remove Youth X from their
program and he was slated to be removed on 4/14/23. Youth X is
cognitively impaired and went AWOL from the facility on 4/11/23.
When police found him, he refused to return to Christ Child. The
police bought him fast food, took him to Christ Child to eat it, and
Youth X still refused to stay at the facility. Police then transported
him to the hospital.
Initially Children’s Hospital denied Youth A's admission as he was
ineligible for hospitalization and had just been discharged two
hours earlier for throwing rocks at moving vehicles in traffic and
other erratic behavior. However, his second time there, he told
hospital staff he felt unsafe at Christ Child House and refused to
return. The hospital held Youth X and reported suspected
abuse/neglect to the appropriate government agency due to his
report of feeling unsafe and refusal to return to his placement.
The government agency who received the report is not
investigating and transferred the complaint to DCWL.
I interviewed Youth X in Children’s Hospital Emergency Room (T-
10) on 4/12/23. He was watching television and Christ Child Staff
1 was supervising him. I introduced myself and he agreed to talk
to me. Youth X presented with a blank stare and severe stuttering.
2

I asked how the staff at Christ Child are mean. After a long
pause, he said “I ask them to stop restraining me, but they keep
doing it. The kids keep calling me ‘B’s’ and stuff.” I asked how
the staff at Christ Child mistreat him. Youth X responded, “By
restraining me…a lot. That’s why I left.”
Specifically, Youth X said Supervisor 3 and 4 restrained him and
then “let go” as he was trying to leave the facility (AWOL) on
4/11/23. He could not remember the reason he wanted to leave.
Asked if he likes the staff at Christ Child, Youth X said he likes
Staff 1 and 2 but dislikes all the rest. He also dislikes the other
youth. Youth X denied that any staff ever caused him any harm.
I interviewed Residential Director (RD) on 4/12/23. She has
worked at the facility for five years. Before Youth X went AWOL,
she said Supervisor 3 and 4 attempted to escort him to his room.
Youth X dropped his weight, announced he was leaving and
walked out the door. There are no records indicating Youth X has
ever been physically restrained.
I asked RD if she was aware that kids call Youth X “B’s.” She
acknowledged that he and another youth did get into a verbal
conflict before he went AWOL on 4/11/23.
I reviewed Supervisor 3 and 4’s employee files.
Past disciplinary actions for Supervisor 3 include:
• 9/23/21 - Verbal warning for violating medication
dispensing policy
• 7/8/21 - 10-day suspension for pushing a youth
• 6/11/20 - 2-day suspension for threatening a youth and
unapproved physical management technique
• 5/23/19 - Verbal warning for unapproved physical
management technique
• 7/26/18 – Verbal warning for unapproved physical
management technique
Past disciplinary action for Supervisor 4 includes:
• 3/18/21 – 5-day suspension for pushing a youth and
unapproved physical intervention
Analysis There is no evidence that Supervisor 3 or 4 mistreated or caused
physical harm to Youth X.
However, it is concerning that both reported they “escorted” the
youth when video shows they clearly restrained him. Moreover,
3

the restraint was unnecessary. (See additional finding below).
For these reasons, there is evidence that Supervisors 3 and 4
require specific retraining on what constitutes a “restraint” and the
conditions in which restraint can be used. Thus, currently both
Supervisors are unable to perform their assigned duties as
leaders of the direct care staff.
Conclusion Violation Established
ADDITIONAL FINDING:
Rule Code & R 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description
(4) Only the least restrictive intervention necessary to prevent
immediate harm to the youth or others may be used and must
follow an individualized set of graduated interventions that avoid
the use of restraints.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth X was physically restrained for refusing to go to his room.
Investigation Video of dining room on 4/11/23 at 6:55pm
CA and I viewed one minute of video of Supervisor 3 and 4’s
reported “escort” of Youth X just prior to his AWOL on 4/11/23. It
shows the youth sitting alone at a dining room table. Supervisors
3 and 4 approach him on either side. Supervisor 4 extends his
hand to the youth, but Youth X stands and pivots away. Both
Supervisors take each of his arms and begin walking him away
from the table, momentarily using a supportive hold. Youth X
immediately pulls away and is unwilling to walk. Rather than
release him, Supervisors tighten their hold using physical force to
restrict his movement. Youth X hops up onto a nearby table and
kicks at staff using the table for leverage. Supervisor 3 initiates a
one-man small child hold (aka basket hold) while Supervisor 4
continues to hold the youth’s left arm. Youth X is jumping,
struggling with his arms, and shifting his weight against the staff’s.
Movement out of the dining room continues at increments until
they reach the threshold of the room. The video ends there and
video from the next room was unavailable.
4

I interviewed Supervisor 3 with CA present on 4/27/23. He has
worked at the facility for 15 years and was last trained in physical
management on 6/26/22. Supervisor 3 said he and Supervisor 4
were trying to “get Youth X to go to his room.” Youth X was on
“restriction” for destruction of property after damaging facility
vehicles. Supervisor 3 said youth on “restriction” receive
recreation, group meals and are allowed to play board games.
However, they are not permitted to play video games or watch
television. After dinner with the group, Supervisor 3 said Youth X
refused to go to his room and remained non-verbal after multiple
attempts to persuade him. Finally, he said he and Supervisor 4
“attempted to transport him.” “We were on his sides trying to start
an escort. He struggled…He became aggressive. We kept
holding about a minute. Youth X never got loose. We got to the
sink. He dropped to the floor. I had his arm. I think Supervisor 4
let him go. It wasn’t textbook. Youth X kept saying ‘I want to
leave.’ We helped him to his feet. He walked with us. There was
no struggle. We opened the exit door to the building because he
said he wanted to leave. We let go and he walked out the door
and gate (off the property). Supervisor 3 insisted “We never
restrained him” and he denied Youth X was physically injured
afterward.
I interviewed Supervisor 4 with CA present. He has worked at the
facility for 3.5 years and was last trained in physical management
on 6/27/22. Earlier in the day, Supervisor 4 said the boys were
acting out, so he decided to separate them into two groups “to
stop the chaos” – one group upstairs to their rooms and the other
downstairs. “I told Youth X he had to go upstairs. I sat 20
minutes talking to him asking him to go. He wouldn’t. Supervisor
3 kept asking. Youth X said ‘No, I want to go home.’ After
multiple attempts to get him to comply, Supervisor 4 said he and
Supervisor 3 positioned themselves on either side of the youth.
“He jumped up…It was a bit of a struggle. Before the sink, it was
still a struggle. Youth X dropped to the floor by the door saying he
wanted to go home. Supervisor 3 held his arm. I rubbed his
(other) arm. We got him up by his arms and escorted him to the
front (exit). We opened the door, and he walked out the building
and gate. I called 911.”
Public Act 116 defines “personal restraint” as the application of
physical force without the use of a device for the purpose of
restraining the free movement of a minor child’s body. It does not
include (ii) Briefly holding a minor child without undue force in
order to calm or comfort him or her or (iii) Holding a minor child’s
5

hand, wrist, shoulder, or arm to safely escort him or her from one
area to another.
Analysis Video shows Youth X sitting quietly at the dining room table
refusing staff directives to move to his room. His behavior was
noncompliant but not harmful to himself or others. After multiple
failed verbal attempts to gain compliance, Supervisors 3 and 4
started to escort Youth X to his room. When the youth physically
resisted, Supervisors did not release him. At that point, what may
have started as an “escort” developed into an unjustified “physical
restraint.” Supervisors 3 and 4 utilized the two-man control hold
and Supervisor 3 used the single-person small child hold. This
restraint could have been avoided as Youth X was not physically
aggressive until Supervisors used force to restrain his free
movement.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
I recommend CA or RD review all video of “escorts” by staff
immediately to verify the youth was truly escorted and not
restrained. All restraints must be documented as such and
reported to the appropriate parties in a timely manner.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is submitted, I recommend this facility
continue its current licensing status.
